captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
[ENGINE REVVING]

The F10M M5 reminds us why we
love this particular recipe
for a motor car.
It's quite simple, really.

Take a load of power, 552
horsepower in this case, 502

foot pounds of torque, throw
it in quite an ordinary

looking body style, and you
have the car for every
opportunity.

In a straight line, this thing
will stay with very, very fast
sports cars.

And it's just as comfortable
as a normal 5 series.

It's just the perfect recipe
for an everyday car.

But for me, most significant
about this car is how much

better optimized, how much more
rounded an object it is
than the car it replaces.

You see, the old E60 M5 was
something I was very fond of.

Really, it was just a racing car
powertrain trapped in a 5
series body style.

That V10 had to be revved like
a lunatic to get anywhere.

The gearbox was a
pain in the ass.

For two or three days, standard
road test procedure,
you'd love the car.

But if you had to live with it,
you'd get completely fed
up with it after a while.

And then, you'd run out of fuel
because it had a thimble
for a fuel tank.

But that car's normally
aspirated V10 was a musical
instrument.

This new M5 has two
noise-killing turbo chargers

which smother intake noise so
effectively, BMW has decided

to pipe fake V8 tunes
into the cabin.
It sounds weird.
But you soon get over it.

One thing I really love about
this car is the way that BMW M

has listened to the feedback
of the people that actually

bought them and ran them, and
answered their questions, and

basically sorted out the issues
they had with the car.

It's got a bigger
fuel tank now.
They got 80 liters.

We've got a brilliant double
clutch gearbox that's so much

better than the last SMG in
here because the automatic
most is seamless.

And in manual mode, it's
like a Ferrari 458.
Wow!
Bang!
Immediate gear changes.

You got loads more torque as
well, so the car doesn't need
to be revved out as much.

But if you do want to rev it
out, it's still very exciting.

So it rights all of the
wrongs of that car.

But here's an Interesting
point for you.

In doing so, the BMW's created a
twin turbocharged car that's

capable of seating four and a
bit people with a big boot

that costs well over
70,000 pounds.

Well, there's another car in
the marketplace that has a

very similar specification
when you look at it
on a piece of paper.

And it's not the most obvious
rival to the M5.

It's currently right
behind me.

And by the looks of things,
it's about to overtake me

because that's what
it seems to do to
everything else on the road.

Of course, I'm not suggesting
for a minute that the R35 GT-R

is a direct rival to the new
M5, because it's not.

You can probably hear just the
ambient noise, the road noise

in this cabin, and it's a
far less refined car.

But it's interesting, isn't it,
that BMW's recipe for the

new M5 kind of moves into
the R35's territory--

twin turbochargers,
big body style.

They do share a lot in common
apart from the way
they bully a road.

Because honestly, no mistake,
nothing bullies a
road like the R35.

It's a quite extraordinary
experience.

And in fact, driving it in the
UK when the weather's bad

brings out all the very best
in the GT-R, all its
extraordinary qualities.

It's not like any other car
because it actually feels like

it's wrestling and pulling grit
from the surface in a way
that no other car does.

It feels like it's driving its
tires into the surface.

It's an extraordinary
experience.

And it just means you have so
much more usable performance.
OK, it's a bit down on power.
There's 542 horsepower.
But you know what?

Even though it's 10 horsepower
shy of the M5, you've probably

got at any one time, because
of the type of four-wheel

drive system, I'd say
another 150 to 200
horsepower at your disposal.

The systems hardly
ever cut in.

And when they do, you don't
really feel them.
This is an extraordinary car.

I've said this before, and
I'll say it again.

A lot of people complain that
the GT-R is a bit soulless,

like a computer game
or something.
Absolute nonsense.

How could anything that's got a
twin turbocharged V6 with a

trans-axle gearbox that then has
to shove a load of power

to the front wheels through a
shaft that comes back out the

side of the car, how can that
possibly be boring?
It's mechanically fascinating.

There were two real reasons
why I got them together.
The first is quite obvious.

They've both got turbocharged
charged engines.
They're quite big on the road.

And they can carry
four people.
The second is very important.

Speaking to the powers that be
back at HQ in New York, these

are two of the most searchable
cars on Google.

Why wouldn't you put
them together?
that's search gold.

So that's why they're
together.

And even though they're not
direct rivals, these two cars

do make you question the other
one in interesting ways.

For example, you don't
appreciate how big and

slightly cumbersome the M5 can
feel at times compared to the

R35 unless you've had a
good blat in this car.

It's just extraordinary the way
that it can be [INAUDIBLE]

kilograms, or a little bit more,
actually, and still feel

so nimble and agile, clever
differentials all the way.

Conversely, the interior of
this car, even though it's

quite interesting the way it's
laid out and quite funky,

quite manga, it's just not got
anything compared to the

quality of the BMW, which is
just a really beautifully

put-together object with
top quality materials.
This is a bit lower rent.

And at the money they're asking
in the UK for a GT-R

now does make you question the
proposition a little bit more.
But I'll tell you what.

My three days with this car
have been exhilarating.
I don't care about the noise.

I think I'd struggle with
it every single day.

But everyone that loves driving
should be prescribed a

few days in a GT-R every
single year.
Because it's just--
well, like this.
[ENGINE HUMMING]
Third, fourth--

it's just incredible, absolutely
incredible.

After the GT-R, the M5
does feel like a
very big heavy car.

1,945 kilograms with a
bit of luggage and
someone else on board.
That's really a two-ton car.

In this day and age, it's
probably not excusable.
It's physically big as well.

I mean, just the space
between me and the
passenger is enormous.

It feels like a 7
series in here.

That's because it's kind
of 7 series side.

But there is one area where the
BMW absolutely crucifies

the GT-R. And that is in
terms of cabin quality.

The GT-R used to be
a 50,000-pound
proposition in the UK.
It's now 70,000 pounds.

That elevates it to an
entirely new level.

Whereas once it used to be this
bargain supercar, it's

now priced like a very premium
sports coupe, and it doesn't

have any of the trim
materials.
It doesn't have the design.

It just lacks the feeling of
quality that this car has.

And it shouldn't be
underestimated.

Because if I was going to spend
a lot of time in either

of them, this is the one
I'd want to be in.
These are very much road cars.

But they're also fast enough
to land you in real
trouble on the road.

So we're heading to the
brilliant Castle Combe

Circuit, which in the lashing
rain is scary with a capital
S.

Let's have a bit of race
mode and a bit of
traction control off--

in a GT-R, 2012 GT-R. It's
absolutely soaking wet at
Castle Combe Circuit.

In some ways, that's a bad place
to test a GT-R. In other
ways, it's the perfect place.

Four-wheel drive, this is
supposed to be the supercar

that can do anything
in any condition.

It is a bit surprising
sometimes, though, in the wet,

because if you give it
a boot full, it does
that straight away.

Forget all this nonsense about
the GT-R being characterless,
bland, and all that rubbish.

This is actually one of the most
interesting cars in the

world to behave badly in,
because everything I try with

the throttle and the steering,
it wants to counteract.

I'm locked in a fight for
the differentials.
Watch this.
So we pitch it in to chicane.

I'll oversteer this one
way, going to make
it obviously there.

Look at how the differential
just said no.

And then it gave me some
oversteer on the exit.

It just wanted to understeer
through there because the

clever brain said I know
Mizuno-san, who developed this

car, would like us to actually
go straight now.

We'll try it again going
the other way.
I do love this.
That's conventional oversteer.
And then back the other way.

Yeah, that felt more
predictable, because I wasn't

fighting the diffs
quite so much.

The classic cornering stance
is like this, though.

We come second gear
into a corner.

As I put the throttle in,
the car oversteers.

But as I correct, then the diff
straightens the guide.
You see that?
The wheel just straightens.

And there's no point in me
fighting that at all.

I've just got to go with it
because that's what the car
wants to do.

This is technically
one of the most
impressive cars ever made--
542 horsepower now for 2012.

I mean, does it get any faster
in these conditions?
It certainly doesn't.

And it's certainly quicker
than the new M5.

So the new M5 may have all the
technology, the jewel clutch
gearbox, the twin turbo V8.
But ultimately, it's a yobbo.
It's a lunatic.

It's basically a V8, a
locking differential,
and two-wheel drive.

But unlike the GT-R, there's
nothing to fight here.

You just put the car in, you
light the [INAUDIBLE] and you
just ride it out.
Woohoo!
Oh, love it.
Absolutely love it.

But what you do find remarkable
about both of these
cars is that you--
[ENGINE REVVING]

--between like 4,000
in the limiter.

They feel normally aspirated,
because you can
modulate the throttle.
So we go in again.

Third gear, I'm going to have
a [INAUDIBLE] of throttle.

I want to come back
out of it again.

Now, I'm just stabbing
it a few times to
try to hold it there.

And it doesn't feel turbocharged
to me.

It's just feels like a normally
aspirated V8.
[TIRES SQUEALING]
[ENGINE REVVING]
[LAUGHS]
You got to love M5s.

There's no other car that
does that stuff.
Are they rivals?
Not really.
Is the GT-R faster?
Yes.

Would you rather live with
the M5 every day?
Of course you would.

Did I enjoy them every mile
and every minute?
Two great cars.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: 2012 BMW M5 vs Nissan GT-R: Driven & Drifted - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text:
Very good video. I couldn't choose! The BMW M5 is more comfortable and in 
the real world probably the best one (daily use considerd etc) but it's not 
as special as the GTR (every street has a 5series in it). I'm not sure how 
the GTR would hold up in everyday use, but it's a lot more special. You 
never see them in traffic here.﻿

comments.author: mrillyrian88

comments.text:
The new Nissan gtr is one of thise understated cars, which is trying to 
compete with top rivals which have already established status among the 
super car world. This personally makes the Nissan (Datsun) more appealing 
in many different aspects which is may not be that obvious. I first saw a 
Nissan gtr back when I was travelling up and down the m3 to my place of 
work, the stance of the car is just so intimidating to all other road user, 
and from that point on I was truly convinced that this was a dark horse of 
the motoring world, you only have to read the technical stats of this car 
and you will have the Italians And Germans shaking in there boots. The 
thing that really struck me is how a company such as Nissan can sell such a 
wide range of cars but still manage to develop a car which will give you 
the performances of super car with the reliability and use ability to rival 
BMWs m range and Audi's quattro and RS ranges﻿

comments.text:
Why if your over 30 would you look an idiot driving a GTR ?  I know 2 
people that have them and they are both over 40  ?  BMW's are a premium 
product, always have been and are priced accordingly. Nissan GTR's are 
another kind of premium product with a different design brief. The BMW is a 
big comfy car that when it wants to, turns in to a bit of a monster. The 
GTR makes no bones about its design brief, it's for going very quickly and 
everything else is secondary to that. Yes on paper they may cost the same, 
seat the same amount of people, but they are completely different cars. ﻿

comments.text:

comments.text:

comments.author: richie baby

comments.text: Audi's don't turn.
comments.author: Begbietheradge

comments.text:
No no no! You are looking at cars for nothing but how they drive and 
handle. This comparison was in all areas; like how comfortable they are, 
how easy they are to live with etc. So it actually is fair competition 
because the M5 makes up in comfort what it lacks in speed. And the latest 
M3 does have a turbo, and those Audis you love don't.

RWD is actually better in some areas. It has less understeer, more balance 
and maybe even more precision if done right. It does have less traction and 
grip but if the tyres are thick and sticky enough it doesn't matter. That 
is why F1 cars and LMP1 cars still use RWD. But at the same time AWD suits 
certain prices, types, shapes of cars and in the case of the GTR (and 
Subaru and Evo) it is better.
comments.author: Ben Ryder

comments.author: Jimbo Cee

comments.text:
Think about it, if you were out looking for a sport saloon that can serve 
as your every day vehicle and your budget was around 70 K... Why would you 
not consider those two? They can both seat four people, they are both 
easily drivable on normal roads, they both produce very similar outputs and 
most importantly they are both within the same price range. This comparison 
actually makes a lot of sense and I have personally thought it through 
before. Realistically though, if you're not too interested in racing or, 
taking your car out for track days then, the M5 probably makes more sense.﻿
comments.author: Shareef Alsayed

comments.text:
I think it's pointless to compare these 2 just because they both have an 
almost identical BHP output. Both the GTR and the M5 are built for 
different purposes. this is just like that review from another company 
comparing the jag F type to a Porsche 911.....I wonder how these guys are 
still not sacked. Seriously, the so called "Reviews" most of you guys do 
don't even look like a review. You focus so much on things that are really 
irrelevant. I know those cars are meant to be fast. But instead of showing 
us how these cars can do power slides on a corner, why can't you guys make 
a proper INFORMATIVE review rather than filling your 13 min video with 
slides and pointless comparison. Seriously, you guys are suppose to be 
experts on the subject matter. Make a proper review.﻿

comments.text: CHECK OUT MY CHANNEL NEW BMW 7 SERIES RELEASED
comments.author: Club Bmw Amg

comments.text:
+Andy Metcalf I prefer the mondeo to the 3 series... I guess I'm a spice 
girls kinda guy.
comments.author: IIXRATEDIIHiTMAN

comments.text:
+IIXRATEDIIHiTMAN Okay I sorta see your point, maybe it's different in the 
UK but the Ford Fusion, American for Mondeo, isn't really in the same 
sector as a 3 series either. It's bigger, cheaper, and worse. Also, that 
line from Top Gear about Mondeo man turning into 3-series man was only 
interesting because the Mondeo had been the best selling car in the UK. But 
now that Mondeo's fallen out of favor, it's quite misleading to say the 3 
series outsells the Mondeo. It's like saying Lady Gaga is outselling Spice 
Girls nowadays.
comments.author: Andy Metcalf

comments.text:
+IIXRATEDIIHiTMAN You said, "BMW, at least in the UK, is the top selling 
manufacturer..." That's simply not true.  

Also, have you ever driven a pick up in America?
comments.author: Andy Metcalf

comments.text:
+Andy Metcalf Wrong. Ford outsells BMW overall on the grounds that they 
don't produce a Ford Fiesta competitor which sells big numbers in the 
sector. Look at the equivalent models though and in 2014; 3 series' sold: 
29,000. vs Ford Mondeo: 12,000.  The A3 sold 6,000 more than that as did 
the Mercedes C-Class. In fact if you add up Audi and BMW sales in the UK 
they outsell the significantly cheaper Fords which is astounding. Compare 
that to the top 10 cars sold in the US and its all pick ups and GM garbage.
comments.author: IIXRATEDIIHiTMAN

comments.text:
According to SMMT, Ford was the top selling manufacture in the UK in 2014. 
BMW was number five, behind Vauxhall, VW, and Audi.  By registration, the 
Ford Fiesta is the #1 selling car in the UK for 2014. The 3 series is #10. 
Combine the Focus and the Fiesta and the two outsell the 3 series 6 to 1. 

Before you drag up an old Jeremy Clarkson quote, you might want to check 
and see if it's still, you know, relevant.  Better yet, come up with your 
own opinions...
comments.author: Andy Metcalf

comments.text:
And I don't think people will see you as an idiot if you are driving a 
$100k driver's car. You could say that about any fast car that isn't comfy 
and prestigious like a BMW
comments.author: Ben Ryder

comments.text: And here in Australia it cost over $70k to buy any new BMW sedan.
comments.author: Ben Ryder

comments.text:

Nope. AWD is on all the time, and adjusted via ECU to compensate for 
different variables based on torque vectoring reads. 4WD, on the other 
hand, has to be manually selected.

comments.text:
Chris Harris is not a d1 drifter, so any reasonably high level drifters 
might well be able to out drift him.
But he was a professional racing driver, so I don't know how you could say: 
"he sucks at driving overall".
Last time I checked, they didn't let people "who suck at driving over all" 
become professional racing drivers.
comments.author: si giggle

comments.text: Watch his Dubai Mclaren P1 vid and re-think it.

goes.

comments.text:
+Victor Estrada hahaahhahaha harder to drift on snow? I get to do it every 
year and it's boring as shit because it's too easy. You haven't been able 
to drift nowhere else than on snow because of underpowered cars so you 
can't even tell what it's like on dry asphalt or even on wet :D Pls man, 
you are clueless so stfu and stop embarrasing yourself. :D It's like slow 
motion drifting on snow, shitloads more time to react and you can't go as 
fast

comments.text:

Sorry not good at expressing myself in this language.

comments.author: Australian Spirit

comments.text:
When you say as cheap as possible .... what exactly do you mean? Have you 
driven a BMW?  They have standards, they are consistent with few 
exceptions, Z8 springs to mind, but like any capitalist company they make 
cars in order to generate profits, so in the sense that every car 
manufacturer does, yes they make cars as cheaply as possible.  Also its 
good to know they are an equal opportunities employer.  They have made and 
still make the best driver's car, all things considered, could almost say 
very good value for money cars!
